questions.text: Which of the following is not supplied by radial nerve?
questions.solution:
After piercing the supinator it emerges in the posterior compartment o the forearm to become the posterior interosseous nerve, which divides immediately into branches supplying all the extensor muscles of the forearm.

Adductor pollicis is supplied by Ulnar nerve.

Reference: J. Maheshwari's 5th Edition of Essential Orthopaedics page no. 65

questions.text: Which of the following is not a test for ulnar nerve:
questions.solution:
Tests for Ulnar nerve:

Card test: palmar interossei

Igawa test: dorsal interossei

Book test/Froments sign: adductor pollicis

Tests for Median nerve:

Pen test: Abductor pollicis brevis

Pointing index/Oschners clasp test

Reference: J. Maheshwari's 5th Edition of Essential Orthopaedics page no. 66,67.

choices.text: Primary pathology is in the acetabulum

questions.text: All the following is true regarding DDH except
questions.solution:
Developmental dysplasia of the hip (DDH) generally includes subluxation (partial dislocation) of the femoral head or complete dislocation of the femoral head from the true acetabulum and acetabular dysplasia meaning ill formed acetabulum.

Acetabular index is angle formed by Hilgenreiner's line and a line from a point on the lateral triradiate cartilage to a point on lateral margin of acetabulum and should be normally < 25° in child older than 6 months. It is seen in xray

Alpha angle is created by lines along the bony acetabulum and the ilium ;normal is > 60°. It is seen in USG.

Beta angle is the angle created by lines along the labrum and the ilium ; normal is < 55°. It is seen in USG.

Reference: Campbell's Operative Orthopaedics 14th edition page no. 1186

Reference: Tachdjian,s Pediatric Orthopaedics 5th edition page no. 499

questions.text: All the following are indications for total knee replacement except
questions.solution:
Absolute contraindications to TKA include recent or current knee sepsis; a remote source of ongoing infection.

The primary indication for TKA is to relieve pain caused by severe arthritis (of any type), with or without significant deformity.

Reference: Campbell's Operative Orthopaedics 14th edition page no. 425

choices.text: Gages sign is a radiological sign of perthes

questions.text: All are true regarding perthes disease except
questions.solution:
Limp in perthes is generally painful. Pain is not the first symptom. It begins with limp initially but later on presents with limp with pain.

Male:Female ratio in Perthes disease is 3.3:1.

Gage sign is the 'v' shaped lucent defect at lateral portion of femoral head epiphysis in Perthes disease.

Reference: Tachdjian,s Pediatric Orthopaedics 5th edition page no. 580,605

questions.text: Which of the following is the most specific sign for Carpal tunnel syndrome
questions.solution:
A carpal compression test (Durkan test), in which direct compression is applied to the median nerve for 30 seconds with the thumbs or an atomizer bulb attached to a manometer, was found to be more specifc (90%) and more sensitive (87%) than either the Tinel or Phalen test.

Tinels sign is generalised test for all compressive neuropathies.

Finkelstein's test is specific test for DeQuervain's tenosynovitis.

Reference: Campbell's Operative Orthopaedics 14th edition page no. 3858

choices.text: Point of pain is distal to that felt in deQuervains disease
At the intersection of 1st extensor compartment (APL&EPB) and 2nd extensor compartment( ECRL&ECRB)
At the intersection of 3rd and 4th extensor compartment tendons
Also called carpal tunnel syndrome with compression of median nerve

questions.text: Which is true regarding Intersection syndrome:
questions.solution:
The presenting symptoms in DeQuervain's disease are usually pain and tenderness at the radial styloid. Pain felt in intersection syndrome is generally proximal to that seen in deQuervains disease as shown in image.

Reference: Campbell's Operative Orthopaedics 14th edition page no. 3850

choices.text: Bamboo spine is the radiological feature

questions.text: All are true regarding ankylosing spondylitis except-
questions.solution:
A strong association has been found between a genetic marker—HLA-B27 and ankylosing spondylosis. Sacro-iliac joints are usually the first to get involved; followed by the spine from the lumbar region upwards.

X-ray of the lumbar spine may show the following:

  • Squaring of vertebrae: The normal anterior concavity of the vertebral body is lost because of calcification of the anterior longitudinal ligament.
  • Loss of the lumbar lordosis.
  • Bridging 'osteophytes' (syndesmophytes).
  • Bamboo spine appearance.

There is also evidence of enthesopathy - calcification at the attachment of the muscles, tendons and ligaments, particularly around the pelvis and around the heel.

Picture frame vertebrae is classical feature of Pagets disease.

Reference: J. Maheshwari's 5th Edition of Essential Orthopaedics page no. 291

questions.text: Which of the following is not a marker of bone formation ?
questions.solution:
Remember markers of bone formation: Bone specific ALP, Osteocalcin/nectin, N & C terminal pro-peptides of type I Collagen [BONC].

Serum N and C telopeptides are markers for bone resorption.

Reference: Rockwood and Green's Fractures in Adult's 8th edition, page no. 614.

choices.text: Calcification of the femoral attachment of MCL

questions.text: Are are false regarding pellagrini steida's disease except
questions.solution:
The presence of calcification along the femoral attachment in the tibial (medial) collateral ligament, as in Pellegrini-Stieda disease, usually is more directly related to trauma, such as a sprain or tear of the tibial collateral ligament. Medial collateral ligament is also known as Tibial collateral ligament.

Osgood-Schlatter disease is an apophysitis/ osteochondritis of the tibial tuberosity that is the result of persistent traction on the apophysis of the tibial tuberosity caused by overuse.

In adolescents, 'jumper's knee' and Sinding-Larsen-Johansson syndrome occur frequently. These are avulsion injuries of the proximal and distal poles of the patella respectively.

Reference: Campbell's Operative Orthopaedics 14th edition page no. 497, 1266 and 1599

questions.text: All are clinical features of Rickets except:
questions.solution:
Craniotabes: This is the manifestation of rickets seen in young infants. Pressure over the soft membranous bones of the skull gives the feeling of a ping pong ball being compressed and released.

  • Bossing of the skull: Bossing of the frontal and parietal bones becomes evident after the age of 6 months.
  • Broadening of the ends of long bones, most prominently around wrists and knees. It is seen around 6-9 months of age.
  • Delayed teeth eruption is noticed in infants.
  • Harrison's sulcus: A horizontal depression, along the lower part of the chest, corresponding to the insertion of diaphragm.
  • Pigeon chest: The sternum is prominent.
  • Rachitic rosary: The costo-chondral junctions on the anterior chest wall become prominent, giving rise to appearance of a rosary.
  • Muscular hypotonia: The child's abdomen becomes protruberant (pot belly) because of marked muscular hypotonia. Visceroptosis and lumbar lordosis occurs.
  • Deformities: Deformities of the long bones resulting in knock knees or bow legs is common presentation of rickets, once the child starts walking.

Brown's tumour: This is an expansile bone lesion, a collection of osteoclasts seen in hyperparathyroidism. It commonly affects the maxilla or mandible, though any bone may be affected.

Reference: J. Maheshwari's 5th Edition of Essential Orthopaedics page no. 310,313.

questions.text: All of the following are tests for subscapularis muscle except:
questions.solution:
BELLY PRESS TEST - Gerber et&al. described the belly press test for patients who have decreased internal rotation. In this test, the patient presses the abdomen with the flat of the hand and attempts to keep the arm in maximal internal rotation. If active internal rotation is strong, the elbow does not drop backward, meaning it remains in front of the trunk. If the strength of the subscapularis is impaired, maximal internal rotation cannot be maintained, the patient feels weakness, and the elbow drops back behind the trunk.

LIFT-OFF TEST

In 1991, Gerber and Krushell described the li$-o# test for detection of an isolated rupture of the subscapularis tendon. With the patient seated or standing, the arm is internally rotated, and the dorsum of the hand is placed against the lower back. If the patient is unable to lift the dorsum of the hand of the back, the test is positive. Electromyography has confirmed that the subscapularis muscle is maximally active with the hand in the midlumbar position and with resistance applied.

BEAR-HUG TEST FOR SUBSCAPULARIS TEAR

The bear-hug test is performed with the patient’s palm of the involved side placed on the opposite shoulder with fingers extended and the elbow positioned anterior to the body. !e patient is asked to hold that position (resisted internal rotation), and the examiner tries to pull the patient’s hand from the shoulder with an external rotation force applied perpendicular to the forearm. The test is considered positive if the patient is unable to hold the hand against the shoulder or if he or she shows weakness of resisted internal rotation of more than 20% compared with the opposite side.

PATTE (HORNBLOWER) SIGN

The Patte sign is used to determine the strength of the teres minor. With the patient standing, the examiner elevates the patient's arm to 90 degrees in the scapular plane and flexes the elbow to 90 degrees. The patient is then asked to laterally rotate the shoulder. Weakness and/or pain constitutes a positive test.

Reference: Campbell's Operative Orthopaedics 14th edition page no. 2381

choices.text: Dorsal scapular nerve is involved in C5 root lesion
Nerve conduction study is best done within 48 hours of injury and helps in localizing the lesion
Pseudomeningocele formation on MRI is characteristic of preganglionic lesions
Positive triple response after histamine injection is seen in pre ganglionic lesion

questions.text: All of the following are true regarding brachial plexus injury except:
questions.solution:
Immediately after injury, conduction proximal and distal to the insult usually elicits a normal response, although stimulation across the injured segment may vary, depending on the presence of axonal or myelin injury. As Wallerian degeneration ensues (within 5 to 10 days), there is a progressive reduction in the amplitude and alteration in the configuration of the evoked potentials. Hence ideal time for NCS is after 2 weeks.

Dorsal scapular nerve arises from ventral ramus of C5 root.

Reference: Campbell's Operative Orthopaedics 14th edition page no. 3283

questions.text: Finkelsteins test is used for the diagnosis of:
questions.solution:
Carpal tunnel syndrome - A carpal compression test (Durkan test), in which direct compression is applied to the median nerve for 30 seconds with the thumbs or an atomizer bulb attached to a manometer, was found to be more specifc (90%) and more sensitive (87%) than either the Tinel or Phalen test.

DeQuervain's tenosynovitis - The Finkelstein test usually is positive in this condition: 'on grasping the patient's thumb and quickly abducting the hand ulnarward, the pain over the styloid tip is excruciating.' Finkelstein stated that this test is 'probably the most pathognomonic objective sign,'

Tennis elbow: COZENS test - Pain is aggravated by putting the extensor tendons to a stretch; for example, by palmar-flexing the wrist and fingers with the forearm pronated.

Golfer's elbow - There is no named test for this condition. But clinically provocative test can be done by fully supinating the forearm and passively extension of elbow, wrist and fingers which causes pain over medial epicondyle of humerus (common flexor origin).

Reference: Campbell's Operative Orthopaedics 14th edition page no. 3850, 3858

Reference: J. Maheshwari's 5th Edition of Essential Orthopaedics page no. 302.

questions.text: 28 year old patients presents to you with giving way of left knee. H/o slip and fall while walking. Clinical examination reveals a positive valgus stress at 30 degree flexion. Your diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Medial collateral ligament: This ligament is damaged if the injuring force has the effect of abducting the leg on the femur (valgus force). It ruptures most commonly from its femoral attachment.

Reference: J. Maheshwari's 5th Edition of Essential Orthopaedics page no. 149.

choices.text: Closed reduction of fracture and re-examine for the pulse

questions.text: 8 year old boy presents with supracondylar fracture. Clinical examination reveals an absent radial pulse. What is your next step:
questions.solution:
Algorithm for pulseless pale limb in supracondylar fractures.

Reference: Rockwood and Wilkin's Fractures in Children's 8th edition, page no. 609.

questions.text: Patient after an RTA presents with ABD+ ER deformity of the hip. What is your probable diagnosis
questions.solution:
Neck of femur & IT fracture: Shortening with ER, but no ABD deformity.

Ref. J. Maheshwari's 5th Edition of Essential Orthopaedics page no.56.

questions.text: Patient presents to you with a comminuted fracture of the left femur. He has a wound measuring 1.5cm over the fracture site. This injury is classified as:
questions.solution:
Gustillo Anderson classification:

Though wound size is between 2-10cm, that belongs to Type-II fracture, as the fracture pattern is comminuted, this injury is classified under typeIII A fracture. As there is no associated vascular injury, it is not type IIIC.

Reference: J. Maheshwari's 5th Edition of Essential Orthopaedics page no.21.

choices.text: It's the other name for undescended scapula
Can be associated with Klippel feil syndrome

questions.text: Sprengels shoulder all are true except:
questions.solution:
Sprengel deformity is characterized as a congenital upward elevation of the scapula in relation to the thoracic cage. !e scapula is commonly hypoplastic and misshapen. Other congenital anomalies may be present, such as cervical ribs, malformations of ribs, and anomalies of the cervical vertebrae (Klippel- Feil syndrome). In about half of patients, an extra ossicle, the omovertebral bone, is present; this is a rhomboidal plaque of cartilage and bone lying in a strong fascial sheath that extends from the superior angle of the scapula to the spinous process, lamina, or transverse process of one or more lower cervical vertebrae which prevents descent of scapula.

Reference: Campbell's Operative Orthopaedics 14th edition page no. 1231

choices.text: Mirels criteria is used to decide if prophylactic fixation is required in pathological lesions
MC cause for pathological fractures is osteoporosis
MC area for pathological fractures neck of femur
Fracture healing is delayed if pathological fractures are due to osteoporosis

questions.text: All are true regarding pathological fractures except:
questions.solution:
A fracture is termed pathological when it occurs in a bone made weak by some disease. Often,the bone breaks as a result of a trivial trauma, or spontaneously. Osteoporosis is the commonest cause of pathological fracture. The bones most often affected are the vertebral bodies (thoracic and lumbar). Other common fractures associated with osteoporosis are fracture of the neck of the femur and Colles' fracture. Fracture healing is delayed in patients with osteoporosis and they require treatment of osteoporosis along with ortgopaedic management of the fracture.

Mirel's criteria is a system used to predict the highest risk of pathological fracture among long bones affected by metastesis.

Reference: J. Maheshwari's 5th Edition of Essential Orthopaedics page no.4.

questions.text: Tuberculosis of the spine investigation of choice is :
questions.solution:
MRI is the investigation of choice in TB spine to evaluate the type and extent of compression of the cord. It also shows condition of the underlying neural tissues, and thus helps in predicting the prognosis in a particular case.

Biopsy: CT guided needle biopsy, or an open biopsy may be required in a case with doubtful diagnosis.

Reference: J. Maheshwari's 5th Edition of Essential Orthopaedics page no.190.

questions.text: A 7 yr old male complains of fever and pain right hip, on examination he has swelling in right hip region, flexion, abduction and external rotation at hip and there is mild reduction in movements in right hip region. On x-ray there is mild increase in medial joint space. diagnosis is :
questions.solution:
FABER is the position, increased medial joint space (Waldenstrom sign) both are seen in septic hip/transient synovitis. > 6 yrs/ mild symptoms points more towards transient synovitis than septic arthritis.

Reference: J. Maheshwari's 5th Edition of Essential Orthopaedics page no.181.

questions.text: All of these constitute to form rotator cuff in shoulder except:
questions.solution:
The strong muscles surrounding the shoulder joint contribute a great deal to the stability of this joint. The important among these are the 'rotator cuff' muscles (supra-spinatus, infra-spinatus, teres minor, sub-scapularis).

Reference: J. Maheshwari's 5th Edition of Essential Orthopaedics page no.88.

questions.text: Spinal injury with no radiological finding is commonly seen in:
questions.solution:
One unique injury in pediatric patients is spinal cord injury without radiographic abnormality (SCIWORA), first described by Pang and Wilberger. !is condition is characterized by a spinal cord injury, either complete or incomplete, in the absence of any radiographic abnormalities. A meta-analysis found that in half the patients, MRI was normal, which carries a better long-term prognosis as well. It is hypothesized to be related to a severe &exion distraction injury of the cervical spine. Cadaver studies have shown that, due to ligamentous laxity, the spinal column in children can undergo 4 to 5 cm of distraction before disruption compared with 4 mm to 5 mm for the spinal cord.

Reference: Campbell's Operative Orthopaedics 14th edition page no. 1548

questions.text: 'Judet' view of x ray is for :
questions.solution:
Judet views are of two types:

Obturator oblique view for viewing Anterior column and posterior wall of acetabulum

Iliac oblique view for viewing Posterior column and anterior wall of the acetabulum

Ref. J. Maheshwari's 5th Edition of Essential Orthopaedics page no.369.
